EPID 684 Spatial Epidemiology University of Michigan School of Public Health

Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="400" height="100"} ## Agenda - Readings - "Good Map ðŸ˜‡, Bad Map ðŸ‘¿" - If time: Overview of Roadmap Project ## Making sense of today's readings - Did the Kirby piece impact your understanding of what spatial epidemiology is or isn't? How? - Is the distinction between spatial epidemiology and medical geography made by Kirby et al. meaningful? - Which of the analytic tools mentioned in this piece are most relevant to your own research or practice interests? - Any points of confusion? Other questions? ```{r} library(countdown) countdown(minutes = 10, warn_when = 60, seconds = 0, play_sound=FALSE) ``` ## Good Map, Bad Map - [Activity](https://zelnotes.io/teaching/EPID684/Activities/Good+Map%2C+Bad+Map) description - [Slides](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1TMGl5Nl5k2K2uO-dv6VQSTEOSrPvZ3u22-7z_rInO_w/edit?usp=sharing) ```{r} library(countdown) countdown(minutes = 15, warn_when = 60, seconds = 0, play_sound=FALSE) ``` ## Roadmap Project - Project is really focused on how to do something useful with spatial ideas and data in public health. - Take a few minutes to look at the components of the assignment. - Think about some of the ideas in the Koch piece; are they relevant to what you are interested in doing? ## Next Time

Making sense of distance and other forms of spatial relatedness
